repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Suralaya Thermal Power Project
            and Sumatera and Kalimantan Power Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit rates the Suralaya Thermal
            Power (STP) Project outcome as moderately satisfactory, with
            unlikely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts, in contrast to the Implementation
            Completion Report (ICR) ratings of unsatisfactory outcomes,
            and substantial institutional development impacts.
            Conversely, it concurs with the ICR ratings of the Sumatera
            and Kalimantan Power (SKP) Project of unsatisfactory
            outcome, and unlikely sustainability, but upgrades
            institutional development impacts from modest to
            substantial. The findings of the Thematic Overview suggest
            that the radically changed circumstances in the Indonesian
            power sector, are conducive to the Bank's continuing
            reluctance to support new generation projects, which may
            have to be reconsidered, and alternative ways of structuring
            mixed public-private generation projects need to be
            explored. Lessons drawn from the performance assessment of
            these two projects include: 1) meticulous coal quality
            monitoring is essential for a plant where minor differences
            in coal characteristics can have a significant impact on
            boiler efficiency, with substantial financial consequences;
            2) a secure long-term supply contract for coal with the
            optimal characteristics for the Suralaya boilers may justify
            the payment of a price premium, because of the financial
            consequences of a poorer heat rate, plant unavailability due
            to more frequent outages, and increased maintenance costs;
            3) an automatic tariff adjustment mechanism can only operate
            satisfactorily under relatively stable macroeconomic
            conditions: variations in the exchange rate, fuel prices,
            and inflation, cannot be dealt with, through a technical
            formula that is de-linked from socio-political
            considerations; and, 4) project objectives should be
            directly linked to project components. Furthermore, compared
            to Specific Investment Loans, an Adaptable Program Loan
            would appear to be a more appropriate lending instrument for
            the pursuit of sector reforms that require consensus
            building, and are particularly suitable instruments in
            countries where the Bank has a regular sequence of lending
            operations in the same sector.

repnme.cdata!: Indonesia - Sumatera and Kalimantan Power Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings show unsatisfactory
            outcomes, unlikely sustainability, and only modest
            institutional development impacts. Despite unfavorable
            outcomes, the project flexibility demonstrated by the quick
            responsiveness to the financial crises, as well as the
            active stakeholder participation during preparation, and
            implementation, did however contribute to the success of the
            project's physical components. But lessons drawn from
            the project are outlined as follows. To avoid discrepancies
            between the status of project works, and actual
            disbursements, contractors' invoicing should be
            streamlined to avoid unnecessary payments delays. Regarding
            resettlement issues - where indeed the livelihoods of
            affected populations are at risk - nongovernmental
            organizations need to maintain strong community relations,
            through an active role during implementation, enhanced by
            strong funding capacity to ensure land acquisition, and
            relocation issues are rightfully implemented. While the
            centralized project management did effectively correct
            actions as needed, demonstrating an effective monitoring,
            and coordination approach, it was however ineffective in
            directing the required changes. It is suggested that a
            programmatic approach to lending, i.e., Adaptable Program
            Lending, in Indonesia's energy sector, is seemingly
            more suitable to support long-term policy objectives, and
            institution building, demonstrated by the unsuccessful
            project outcomes of this operation's traditional
            approach to investment lending. Finally, the State
            Electricity Corporation - with a large investment program -
            was certainly not the company suitable for the use of
            "rate of return on revalued assets" covenant, to
            measure financial performance.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Besai Hydroelectric Power
            Project : resettlement and rehabilitation action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of this plan are: 1) to
            ensure that project affected people (PAP) are compensated
            for any losses of land, vegetation and crops and buildings
            and structures; and 2) to ensure that the income level and
            the living standard of the PAP shall not be reduced, but
            rather improved. To achieve this objective, Perusahaan Umum
            Listrik Negara (PLN) is committed to do the following: 1) to
            ensure that all PAPs, both landowners, formally owners and
            "land encroachers", and non-landowners are
            compensated at replacement value for all assets; 2) to
            ensure that for land compensation, if any, will be completed
            before the start of actual construction work; 3) to ensure
            that couseling, technical assistance and credit facilities
            will be made available to those wishing to engage in small
            business and other trade activities; and 4) to ensure that
            education and training will be provided in vocational
            training school if desired by the affected people.

repnme.cdata!: Indonesia - Sumatera and Kalimantan Power Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sumatera and Kalimantan Power
            Project has a policy component and several physical
            components. The policy component of the project entails: a)
            establishing a policy framework for private sector
            participation; b) restructuring the State Electricity
            Corporation (PLN) and establishing commercial operations as
            a limited liability company; c) implementing framework for
            regulatory oversight of the power sector; and d) introducing
            formula-based power tariffs, as well as bulk power purchase
            and supply tariffs. The physical component of the project
            will finance economical and environmentally sustainable
            expansion of PLN's generation capacity, with associated
            transmission lines, in the islands of Sumatera and
            Kalimantan and improve service reliability. The physical
            components are: a) construction of a hydoelectric power
            plant with related transmission facilities; b) construction
            of a mine-mouth lignite fired thermal power plant with
            related transmission facilities; c) procurement of two
            barge-mounted power plants; and d) technical assistance.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Sumatera and Kalimantan Power
            Project : environmental impact assessment coal projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The environmental impacts of the
            Sumatera and Kalimantan Power Project can be subdivided into
            three categories: 1) preconstruction; 2) construction; and
            3) post construction.  Preconstruction impacts include
            investigative surveys, as well as the processes of land
            acquisition and resettlement.  The main impacts to be
            expected during the construction stage are: land clearing
            and preparation, movement and operation of heavy
            construction equipment, the extraction or borrow of local
            materials for construction, the disposal of spoil, and the
            concentration of a fairly large construction labor force,
            many of whom may come from outside the local region.  The
            expected environmental impacts from the power plant will be
            caused by: gaseous emissions from the chimney liquid
            effluent and solid wastes from the power plant, housing
            colony and office facilities.  This study includes both an
            environmental management plan and an environmental
            monitoring plan outlining short term and long term objectives.
